items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Torksey river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. 
Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.  Standing water remains in the surrounding area of Girton with access limited by vehicles. 
No further rainfall is forecast. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. 
We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday, 14/01/2025. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and please do not drive through floodwater, as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are still high but stable on the lower reaches of the river Churn. Flooding of low lying land and roads is still possible today, 13/01/25, particularly in Cerney Wick.  It is forecast to remain dry today and overnight. We expect river levels to remain steady and begin a slow fall over the coming days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 14/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the Lower River Cherwell. However, flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected to continue today, 13/01/2025, especially in the Thrupp area. It is forecast to remain dry today and overnight. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 14/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are stable or dropping along the River Windrush. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today, 13/01/25, especially in the Bourton On The Water and Newbridge areas.  It is forecast to remain dry today and overnight. We expect river levels to continue dropping slowly over the coming days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 14/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are still falling steadily on the lower River Ray. However, the flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 13/01/2025, especially in the Islip areas.  It is forecast to remain dry today and overnight. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 14/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are slowly falling but still remain high due to the previous rainfall.  We are continually monitoring the situation and the river levels.
All areas between Ringwood and Christchurch could be affected and include all tributaries. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
Flood water is now receding from the causeway at Sutton Gault.

This information is correct as of 18:00 on Monday 13/01/2025.

The causeway at Welney has approximately 10 centimetres of water on the road. Flood water is receding from the causeway at Sutton Gault. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. 

The Environment Agency is liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road at Welney. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. 

The weather forecast is for no further rain for the next 5 days. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself at risk. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 8am on Tuesday 14/01/2025.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels remain high on the Lower River Colne and Frays River, but are steadily falling. Flooding may continue to affect locations near the Colne, Frays, Wraysbury, and Poyle Channel, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. No flooding to properties is expected. 

River levels have been steadily falling over the last few days. With dry weather over the coming days, river levels are expected to continue falling. We are monitoring the situation closely. 

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and monitor local water levels and weather conditions. 

This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow morning, Tuesday 14th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels remain high but continue to fall at the Walcot River gauge following recent heavy rainfall and snowmelt. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.  

Light rainfall is possible over the next 36 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow, Tuesday 14/01/25. We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 10am on Tuesday 14/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen but are now slowly starting to fall on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of a period of sustained rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 13/01/25, especially in the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey. The forecast for the next 24 hours is dry. River levels have peaked and are slowly falling but we expect river levels to remain high over the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 14/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent rainfall and snowmelt. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. 

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   

Light rainfall is possible over the next 36 hours. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences. 

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated by 10am on Tuesday 14/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The Parrett, Yeo, Isle and tributary rivers rose as a result of the heavy rain two weekends ago.
Water has overtopped and and flooded the surrounding low-lying moors. Floodwaters still persist. 
The weather outlook for Monday and Tuesday appears dry, with no significant rainfall expected. This Flood Alert will remain in force until water levels start to drop below the threshold. 
We will continue to monitor any further rainfall, the river levels and the overall situation.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m.
For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 14/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.    

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further significant rainfall is forecast. We continue to monitor the situation.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Avon in Worcestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.    

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further significant rainfall is forecast. We continue to monitor the situation.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: West Somerset Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
Flooding is still possible as the river near Beggearn Huish in West Somerset remains above the flood alert threshold of 0.35m following heavy rainfall two weekends ago. However, water levels look stable and continue to slowly fall. 
The chance of precipitation for Monday appears very low. While the Flood Alert may remain in place through Tuesday, we are closely monitoring the weather forecast, river levels, and overall conditions. If the dry forecast holds, the alert could be lifted soon.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 14/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Rede
items.message:
High river levels caused by melting snow may lead to flooding this afternoon.

Flooding is possible from 3:45 PM today (Monday, 13/01/2025).

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Rede, with low lying land, roads and footpaths in the Otterburn Mill area expected to be most affected. Property flooding is not expected.

River levels are expected to remain high overnight and into tomorrow morning as the snow continues to melt.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
Floodwaters persist at Currymoor Reservoir following the significant rise of the River Tone caused by heavy rainfall two weekends ago. We are closely monitoring any anticipated rainfall, river levels and flood assets.
Water enters via Hookbridge spillway whilst the River level exceeds 7.45m. Cutts Road floods as the Currymoor Drain level is above 5.75m, and New Road as the Drain level is above 6.18m.
For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels.
The weather outlook for Monday and Tuesday appears dry, with no significant rainfall expected. Consequently, water levels are unlikely to rise.
Pumping operations continue at Currymoor with all available pumps. Water levels are gradually receding and the Parrett Relief Channel is running.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 14/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels remain high and are expected to respond to recent rainfall, levels are likely to respond from the 8th of January onwards. Levels are very reactive to further rainfall. 

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 14/1/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Coln and its tributaries
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are still high but stable on the River Coln. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 13/01/25, particularly in the Fossebridge area. It is forecast to remain dry today and overnight. We expect river levels to start to fall slowly later today. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 14/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Hull catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message: Levels have now fallen below levels of concern in this area. Snowmelt may push levels up again in the coming days, and so we will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if required.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently stable at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. However, groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next week.

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall, and levels may rise again in response to rainfall over the last week. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore to be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 14/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently slowly falling at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley. However, groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the coming weeks if levels begin rising again.

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall, and levels may rise again in response to rainfall over the last week. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore to be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 14/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high and rising. In the last week, over half a month’s rain (69mm) has been recorded at Bishops Sutton. During this time, the level at Preston Candover has risen by 30cm. In Preston Candover and Old Alresford, a small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding. Septic tanks in Old Alresford will be struggling to operate effectively. Further rainfall is forecast on Wednesday 08/01/2025 and Friday 10/01/2025, with up to 15mm expected on each day. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising slowly for around 2 weeks in response to this rain. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 14/01/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn and early Winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn and early Winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 15th January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn and early Winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. This rise is from levels which were already high from the previous Winter. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn and early Winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 15th January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently rising very slowly at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton following rainfall over recent weeks.

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. We expect levels to continue rising slowly over the coming week and levels will remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Low lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment
items.message: Levels have now fallen below levels of concern in this area. Snowmelt may push levels up again in the coming days, and so we will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this warning if required.

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: River levels in the Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston remain high as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the rivers is expected to continue. No further rain is forecast for the next few days, however we expect the rivers to remain high and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the rivers. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine on 14/01/25, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels have fallen by 7cm since Monday 06/01/2025 following a week of mostly dry weather. Groundwater levels in the village peaked earlier than expected and below the level we would expect cellar flooding impacts to occur. During this week, the weather is expected to remain fairly dry. Groundwater levels are expected to continue to slowly fall. We continue to monitor the groundwater levels and weather forecast. If further heavy and persistent rainfall affects the area during the winter, then groundwater flooding impacts are a possibility. We will issue further advice if we think groundwater levels will affect property.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in the villages surrounding Andover are high and slowly rising. In the last week, the level at Clanville has risen by 60cm. In Appleshaw, a small number of properties are expected to begin experiencing cellar flooding from today (13/01/2025). In Hatherden, a small number of cellars could be affected from Wednesday (15/01/2025). Groundwater is affecting the sewerage network at Penton Mewsey and the main road into Penton Grafton is flooded. Groundwater will emerge in many of the ditches and roads in most villages. During this week, the weather is expected to remain mostly dry. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising for another week in response to the rain recorded in early January. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove any valuables from cellars. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Monday 20/01/2025.

items.description: River Trent at Girton
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, standing water remains around the village of Girton with limited access.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: In Deane and Ashe, groundwater levels are high and continue to rise slowly. In the last 7 days, the level has risen by 34cm. In the last 3 months, 265mm of rain has been recorded at Overton. This is more than the long-term average rainfall expected for this period. The River Test will be flowing in Deane and Ashe. Rising groundwater will also begin to affect the ability of septic tanks to operate properly. During this week, the weather will remain fairly dry, but groundwater will continue to rise for most of January, in response to the rainfall recorded at the beginning of the month. We continue to monitor the forecast. In Deane, we would like residents to prepare for cellar flooding impacts, which are possible by the end of January. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. We will update this Flood Alert by 17:00 on Monday 20/01/2025.
